completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE ROBERTS
completeLines.speech: We'll hear argument next in Evans versus Chavis. Ms. Chatman.

completeLines.speaker: CHATMAN
completeLines.speech: Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court: The Ninth Circuit decision in the court below was wrong, for three reasons. It adopted a rule that frustrates Congress's intent to protect Federal Courts from hearing stale claims and to respect the finality of State Court convictions. It does so by improperly and arbitrarily adopting a conclusive presumption that misunderstands or ignores State law and practice. And it is inconsistent with this Court's decision in Carey versus Saffold. If the Federal Courts, on the other hand, complete their analysis of the Federal question of tolling the AEDPA statute of limitations by deciding whether a State petition was timely before granting tolling, it can properly dismiss more Federal petitions on statute-of-limitations grounds and can avoid litigating stale claims on the merits. Any difficulties in doing so can be ameliorated by the limited nature of the State-law inquiry and adoption of a 60-day presumption of timeliness.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE GINSBURG
completeLines.speech: But that's something -- where would we -- we would just pick that number, that --

completeLines.speaker: CHATMAN
completeLines.speech: The 60 days?

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE GINSBURG
completeLines.speech: Yes. Because that's a normal appeal period?

completeLines.speaker: CHATMAN
completeLines.speech: Well, Justice Ginsburg, when California does look to timeliness in proceeding from one lower court to a higher court, then we see that it contemplates that a -- that a litigant will proceed in 60 days or less, because -- and the reason we have to turn to analogies is because nothing in California law requires the appellate courts in State habeas to look to that particular period of time between the lower court decision and proceeding to that court, because they're courts of original jurisdiction. So, they look at how long the prisoner proceeded from conviction to their court, as a whole. But the reason that we need to figure out this period is because this Court, in Carey versus Saffold, has said that our system functions enough like an appellate system to bring those periods into the tolling provision. So, when --

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE KENNEDY
completeLines.speech: Well, can't --

completeLines.speaker: CHATMAN
completeLines.speech: -- we look --

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE KENNEDY
completeLines.speech: -- the -- can't the California courts adopt a -- give us a 60-day rule, or a 30-day rule, or a 90-day rule? And if they don't do it, why should we do it?

completeLines.speaker: CHATMAN
completeLines.speech: Up to this point, they have not done so. And I think that is because, as I said, they are looking at the time from conviction. How long did it take the prisoner to get to their court with their claims? And how -- and how long they take properly proceeding up the ladder through the courts is just one factor that they look at. And they --

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: I don't know how this came about. I mean -- I mean, I'm asking both sides the same question. It'll sound very favorable to you, but if you answer it just yes, because it's favorable to you, I might learn, later, I was wrong, and you won't have had a chance to answer. So, I want your honest opinion on this. I don't know how this happened. And I don't know -- did you ask for en banc?

completeLines.speaker: CHATMAN
completeLines.speech: I'm sorry, how the 3-year delay happened?

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: No. I don't know how the California Court could have read the opinion -- which, of course, I wrote for the Court, so maybe I am reading things into it that weren't there -- but I don't know how any judge could read that opinion we wrote and come to this conclusion. I thought that it said, you know, on -- that there are three issues -- what's the word "pending"? Does the word "pending" apply to the time period between when the lower court decides a case and you appeal? That's typically 20 days or 30 days.

completeLines.speaker: CHATMAN
completeLines.speech: Correct.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: Are those 20 days or 30 days counted in the tolling period? I thought part one clearly said the answer is yes. Then we looked at California, and they don't have the words "20 days" or "30 days." They say "reasonable time." And then we said, "Still applies, because 'reasonable time' is probably 20 or 30 days." They don't have a radically different rule; it's a similar rule. Then we come to part three, and it says, "This is 45 days." There's -- no 4 and a half months, wasn't it?

completeLines.speaker: CHATMAN
completeLines.speech: Uh-huh.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: This isn't just 20 or 30 days.

completeLines.speaker: CHATMAN
completeLines.speech: Uh-huh.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: So, is it timely?

completeLines.speaker: CHATMAN
completeLines.speech: Uh-huh.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: And, there, I thought the Court said -- I mean, I was reading it -- say, "Well, it's hard to say, because there might have been excuses for the delay." What about the words that were written there, "on the merits"?

completeLines.speaker: CHATMAN
completeLines.speech: And there was an equitable- --

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: On --

completeLines.speaker: CHATMAN
completeLines.speech: -- -tolling question.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: But that had nothing to --

completeLines.speaker: CHATMAN
completeLines.speech: Right.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: -- do with the case. The lack of diligence had nothing to do with this aspect of the case. But, what about the words "on the merits"? And there, what I think the court wrote is that the fact that it says "on the merits" doesn't prove it -- what -- it doesn't prove that it was timely. Why? And then I listed a bunch of reasons. There are reasons. Sometimes courts say "on the merits," even though it's delayed. All right? They say "on the merits." Or because they want to tell the prisoner or -- there are a lot of reasons why, all of which are listed. So, we send it back to see whether this 4-and-a-half-month delay, given the excuses, was still timely. We -- all right?

completeLines.speaker: CHATMAN
completeLines.speech: Yes.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: Now --

completeLines.speaker: CHATMAN
completeLines.speech: Justice --

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: -- we now get a case where it's 3 years.

completeLines.speaker: CHATMAN
completeLines.speech: Uh-huh.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: And the court says, "It's timely, because they used the word 'on the merits.'" But I thought -- I said, in the opinion, I thought the court adopted that the words "on the merits" do not decide the matter.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SCALIA
completeLines.speech: Isn't it --

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: Now, what do you --

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SCALIA
completeLines.speech: -- worse than that?

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: -- do in those circumstances?

completeLines.speaker: CHATMAN
completeLines.speech: Justice Breyer, I could not agree --

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: No, but did --

completeLines.speaker: CHATMAN
completeLines.speech: -- with you more.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: -- you ask for rehearing en banc? Because any judge, including me, can make a mistake. What did you do?

completeLines.speaker: CHATMAN
completeLines.speech: We petitioned for certiorari in this Court.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: And you didn't ask for a hearing en banc.

completeLines.speaker: CHATMAN
completeLines.speech: No, we did not.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: Well, why, when you --

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SCALIA
completeLines.speech: Would --

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: -- get a fair -- because any judge can make a mistake --

completeLines.speaker: CHATMAN
completeLines.speech: The --

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: -- why don't you just go and ask the Ninth Circuit to say, "Look, this is not -- read the opinion, read what they said. Correct it."

completeLines.speaker: CHATMAN
completeLines.speech: This is not the first time that we have tried to take that approach with the Ninth Circuit on this issue. They -- on remand, in Saffold versus Carey, they made the same mistake, and the rehearing has got us nowhere -- asking for a rehearing. And so, we felt that in order to get this clarified as soon as possible, it seems futile to ask for rehearing when on the -- when we had not been successful before.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SCALIA
completeLines.speech: Yes. Well this --

completeLines.speaker: CHATMAN
completeLines.speech: This is, by the way --

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SCALIA
completeLines.speech: -- this case is different, actually, from the one that Justice Breyer put, because, in this case, the California Supreme Court didn't say --

completeLines.speaker: CHATMAN
completeLines.speech: Uh-huh.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SCALIA
completeLines.speech: -- "on the merits." It said nothing at all. It just disposed of it. So, the question presented is quite different.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: It's worse.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SCALIA
completeLines.speech: It's whether -- not whether it can be, nonetheless, timely when they say "on the merits," but whether it can be, nonetheless, timely when they don't say anything at all.

completeLines.speaker: CHATMAN
completeLines.speech: But --

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SCALIA
completeLines.speech: I would think it's an a fortiori case, in other words.

completeLines.speaker: CHATMAN
completeLines.speech: And the Ninth Circuit is treating it as if it were the same sort of decision that was before this Court in Carey versus Saffold. It is a decision on the merits. And they are reading that as excluding any other possible grounds that might have existed for the denial in that case.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: You're representing the attorney general of California, and you have a lot of litigation in the Ninth Circuit. It's -- I mean, the other side's going to answer on the merits, if they can. And they're in an awkward position here, I understand. But I need to know what to -- what do you think we should do? I mean, here, we write an opinion, and they --

completeLines.speaker: CHATMAN
completeLines.speech: Uh-huh.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: -- it seems to perhaps, inadvertently or not -- and the reason I turn to you is, judges are busy, they have huge dockets --

completeLines.speaker: CHATMAN
completeLines.speech: Yes.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: And, often, unless it's very clearly pointed out by the lawyers, or the lawyers take action, you get -- waste everybody's time and money.

completeLines.speaker: CHATMAN
completeLines.speech: Uh-huh. Well, I think the answer is to instruct the Federal Courts that, when they're undertaking this inquiry of whether an application is pending during the intervals, a Federal question that has a State-law component, then they must apply the State law to figure out if it's timely. And, you know, as this Court said in Carey the -- versus Saffold -- it's a matter of whether it's timely; it's not a matter of the basis of the State Court decision. And in the context of California, I think the answer is to adopt a presumption of 60 days, because that is the most analogous --

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE GINSBURG
completeLines.speech: In -- even if, as he alleged, he was unable to do anything in --

completeLines.speaker: CHATMAN
completeLines.speech: Uh-huh.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE GINSBURG
completeLines.speech: This is a layperson. He said, "I tripped in the intermediate appellate court, because I didn't do any research. And so, I wanted to do better, but they gave me a job where, during the hours that the library was open" --

completeLines.speaker: CHATMAN
completeLines.speech: Uh-huh.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE GINSBURG
completeLines.speech: -- "I had to be at work. And that's why it took me all this time."

completeLines.speaker: CHATMAN
completeLines.speech: Uh-huh.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE GINSBURG
completeLines.speech: Now, is that -- suppose the prison locks down someone and says, "You can't go to the library."

completeLines.speaker: CHATMAN
completeLines.speech: This is an easy decision for the Federal Court, even on these facts. Okay, this Petitioner has taken longer than 60 days, and he's offered an explanation. But if you look at his explanation, on its face, it's completely inadequate to account for a 3-year delay, because he doesn't take action to get -- to get library access for an entire year after the Court of Appeals decision denying his application is issued. Then he spends 3 months, quite correctly, going through the administrative procedures of the prison to get a job change. And he does, in fact, get a job change 3 months later -- about 3 months later. Then, he waits still more than another year before he files his petition in the California Supreme Court presenting essentially the same claims, same facts, same law.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: So, in other words, he delays, after he gets the library access, for an extra year.

completeLines.speaker: CHATMAN
completeLines.speech: Yes, he does. Now, he --

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: Now, is there any excuse they're making for that? Because if you don't tell me, they're --

completeLines.speaker: CHATMAN
completeLines.speech: Later on --

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: -- going to tell me.

completeLines.speaker: CHATMAN
completeLines.speech: -- later on, once he gets to Federal Court --

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: Yes.

completeLines.speaker: CHATMAN
completeLines.speech: -- he offers the explanation that the prison was on lockdowns. There are several problems with that assertion; the first being, it wasn't presented to the State Court, so it's -- it cannot cure his State untimeliness. The second being that he doesn't offer specific dates or explain how it prevented him from filing his petition. And the third problem is that State prisons provide procedures during lockdowns to get library materials to prisoners.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE STEVENS
completeLines.speech: Can I ask a rather probably sort of stupid question? But I gather there are a large number of these cases disposed of by a postcard. Would there be anything wrong if the California Supreme Court said, "We're going to have two postcards. One says that 'the delay was unreasonable, denied'; and the other said, 'there's nothing to the merits, denied'" -- you use two postcards -- wouldn't that solve all the problems?

completeLines.speaker: CHATMAN
completeLines.speech: The problem with that is -- certainly, it would solve things, but the problem with that is, it would require the -- require the California courts to make both of those determinations in every case. And, as it is now, they use a procedure much like --

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE STEVENS
completeLines.speech: But they could adopt a 60­ day rule, or a 90-day rule, and then just, when they decided to not follow the rule, they'd put a check on ­ - say, "Well, we did look at the merits in this case."

completeLines.speaker: CHATMAN
completeLines.speech: They could do that --

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SCALIA
completeLines.speech: Under our current law, it wouldn't make any difference, would it? Because even if they sent the "on the merits" postcard, Carey versus Saffold says --

completeLines.speaker: CHATMAN
completeLines.speech: Correct.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SCALIA
completeLines.speech: -- it doesn't matter.

completeLines.speaker: CHATMAN
completeLines.speech: That's true. And that is why I say they would have to make both determinations, because --

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SOUTER
completeLines.speech: Well, may --

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE ROBERTS
completeLines.speech: Well, it might --

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SOUTER
completeLines.speech: -- may I -- no, go ahead.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE ROBERTS
completeLines.speech: I was just going to say, it might matter if they had another postcard that said it's untimely, and they didn't send that. That would be a whole different situation, right?

completeLines.speaker: CHATMAN
completeLines.speech: That's true, but we are -- we are engaging here in trying to tell the California State Courts how to dispose of these cases, which I am really not sure is an appropriate thing for us to do. They're --

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SOUTER
completeLines.speech: Well, but --

completeLines.speaker: CHATMAN
completeLines.speech: -- using a --

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SOUTER
completeLines.speech: -- if we --

completeLines.speaker: CHATMAN
completeLines.speech: -- procedure --

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SOUTER
completeLines.speech: -- if we decided it -- it was at least appropriate to give a hint, aren't we in a little bit better position than you suggested, in the light of Carey? Because in -- is -- correct me if I'm wrong, but I thought, in Carey, the State order was not merely that it was on the merits, but that it was on the merits and it was untimely. In other words, it said A and B. And we said, you know, "That's ambiguous," to start with, and then we went on and said, "You know, sometimes 'merits' don't mean merits." But if the State were to revise its procedure and say, "We're either going to say A or we're going to say B, and that's our reason," and they said, "It's on the merits" or "it's untimely," wouldn't it make sense for us, even in the light of Carey, to say, "Okay, we'll accept that as the -- as the State's reason"?

completeLines.speaker: CHATMAN
completeLines.speech: If they were to do that. But I don't anticipate the State Courts adopting that practice, because it would double their work. They would have to make both decisions, merits and untimeliness.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SOUTER
completeLines.speech: I don't --

completeLines.speaker: CHATMAN
completeLines.speech: It --

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SOUTER
completeLines.speech: -- see why. If they're going to follow something like a prima facie 60-day rule, and it's -- it's on day 65, all they've got to say is, "It's untimely."

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SCALIA
completeLines.speech: Well, in this --

completeLines.speaker: CHATMAN
completeLines.speech: But the --

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SCALIA
completeLines.speech: -- in this case, in order to determine it was untimely, they would have presumably had to have gone into the factual analysis of whether the prison was on lockdown, whether he delayed for a year after getting the materials, and all of that stuff. So, it's a lot easier for them, when the merits of it seem to them absolutely clear, to simply deny it on the merits and not reach the "timely" question.

completeLines.speaker: CHATMAN
completeLines.speech: And that --

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SCALIA
completeLines.speech: But the "timely" question is still before Federal Courts. That's what we said in Carey versus Saffold. So --

completeLines.speaker: CHATMAN
completeLines.speech: I agree. And they --

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SCALIA
completeLines.speech: -- although they can avoid it, we can't.

completeLines.speaker: CHATMAN
completeLines.speech: And that -- and that is the way the State Courts are approaching these cases. They, for the most part, will look first for a prima facie case, and in -- much like the Federal Courts do in Federal habeas under Rule 4, where they scream for frivolous petitions that can be dismissed outright without asking for a response from the warden or instituting briefing, then they can deny those summarily. And the reason why they cannot just decide timeliness is because then the Ninth Circuit will interpret that as not reaching the merits, and we will have a problem of deference. So, if they were to decide one explicitly, they'd have to decide the other, the way things stand now. And I --

completeLines.speaker: CHATMAN
completeLines.speech: -- as a --

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE STEVENS
completeLines.speech: -- I must say, I don't quite follow the -- why couldn't they simply say it's untimely? Wouldn't that -- that it -- there was -- it was not pending during this period, because it -- 3 years elapsed, and that's unreasonable. Wouldn't that end the case?

completeLines.speaker: CHATMAN
completeLines.speech: It would, but it's not a State- law question. They don't -- whether it's pending during that period is not a --

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE STEVENS
completeLines.speech: No, I understand --

completeLines.speaker: CHATMAN
completeLines.speech: -- State law --

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE STEVENS
completeLines.speech: -- but whether --

completeLines.speaker: CHATMAN
completeLines.speech: -- question, because --

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE STEVENS
completeLines.speech: -- it was a reasonable time to file is a State-law question.

completeLines.speaker: CHATMAN
completeLines.speech: Whether he took a reasonable time from the lower -- from time of conviction to their court is the only State-law question --

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE STEVENS
completeLines.speech: Well, isn't the --

completeLines.speaker: CHATMAN
completeLines.speech: -- because of the --

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE STEVENS
completeLines.speech: Doesn't the --

completeLines.speaker: CHATMAN
completeLines.speech: -- original --

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE STEVENS
completeLines.speech: -- California Supreme Court sometimes decide that the time between the intermediate court's decision and the filing in the California Supreme Court -- don't they ask whether that was reasonable?

completeLines.speaker: CHATMAN
completeLines.speech: I have --

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE STEVENS
completeLines.speech: Or they only relate it back to the day of the conviction?

completeLines.speaker: CHATMAN
completeLines.speech: I have only seen one case in California where they specifically addressed that particular interval because the Attorney General raised it, and that's Moss -- In Re Moss, which is cited in the red brief.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE STEVENS
completeLines.speech: May I ask that, if you had a case in which the Attorney General raised the -- say, this case, and yet -- and say California Supreme Court wrote an opinion in which it said, "Now, 3 years has gone by, but the prisoner has given us a very elaborate explanation," as Justice Ginsburg suggested, "and we find that explanation sufficient; therefore, we conclude that, even though it was 3 years, it was a reasonable time; and, therefore, we're going to address the merits. And we now address the merits and say you lose." Now, in that case, would it be pending, for our purposes?

completeLines.speaker: CHATMAN
completeLines.speech: Yes, because the State Court found it timely, and that would be --

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: It would? I thought --

completeLines.speaker: CHATMAN
completeLines.speech: -- that would be --

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: -- that was --

completeLines.speaker: CHATMAN
completeLines.speech: -- the end of --

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: -- an open --

completeLines.speaker: CHATMAN
completeLines.speech: -- the matter.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: -- question, frankly. I mean, I can't imagine California would do this, but I guess if California did say that, "The period of time between the time you lost in the District Court and the time you filed, in every other State, is 30 days, but, in California, it's a reasonable time. And what we mean by a 'reasonable time' is 3 years, without any excuses" -- I guess, then, maybe the dissent in Carey v. Saffold would have been right in respect to that.

completeLines.speaker: CHATMAN
completeLines.speech: If --

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: It would have said that that isn't pending under Federal law, whether California says it or not. So, the role of the Federal law versus the State law, I thought we left open.

completeLines.speaker: CHATMAN
completeLines.speech: I think this Court, in Carey versus Saffold, and in Pace versus DiGuglielmo, has stressed the importance of deferring to State-law determinations --

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: But you can't --

completeLines.speaker: CHATMAN
completeLines.speech: -- State Court --

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: -- defer to something --

completeLines.speaker: CHATMAN
completeLines.speech: -- determinations.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: -- under this statute, where Congress wrote the word "pending." And I wouldn't have thought they did have in mind a --

completeLines.speaker: CHATMAN
completeLines.speech: Uh-huh.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: -- State that says, "It's pending, even though you have no excuse and didn't file anything for 3 years, your appeal." Now, I haven't heard that fully briefed and so forth, so I hesitate to express a final conclusion on it. But it --

completeLines.speaker: CHATMAN
completeLines.speech: Well, it's --

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: -- since it's never going to come up, I don't think, I don't know I have to have a final conclusion.

completeLines.speaker: CHATMAN
completeLines.speech: I don't think so. But it's pending -- it's pending while -- if it's timely under State law. And if the State Court has already spoken to State law, I don't know that there's a question left for the Federal Court. I think -- I think they say, "Okay, this was timely, and, therefore, pending during the interval." But --

completeLines.speaker: CONNOR
completeLines.speech: Now, you want us to apply a presumption that a petition is timely if it's filed within 60 days. But California doesn't apply such a presumption, does it?

completeLines.speaker: CHATMAN
completeLines.speech: No, it does --

completeLines.speaker: CONNOR
completeLines.speech: And --

completeLines.speaker: CHATMAN
completeLines.speech: -- not, but --

completeLines.speaker: CONNOR
completeLines.speech: -- where do we get that? I mean, where does that come from?

completeLines.speaker: CHATMAN
completeLines.speech: Where that comes from is, if you look to the closest analogous State procedures -- say, direct appeal from a conviction -- then you're allowed 60 days to go to the next -- to the appellate court. Similarly, if the State appeals the grant of habeas relief -- the State, unlike the defendant, can appeal -- then the State gets 60 days. So, when California thinks -- when California quantifies the concept of reasonableness in the appellate context, they do so in terms of 60 days or less. And I say "or less," because State habeas is actually supposed to be a quicker process than the appellate process.

completeLines.speaker: CONNOR
completeLines.speech: Well, shouldn't we leave it to California to adopt such a presumption?

completeLines.speaker: CHATMAN
completeLines.speech: California's not going to do that, because it's not a State-law question. It's just not a State-law question. But it's -- I think it's acceptable for a Federal Court to adopt a presumption to assist them in deciding a State-law issue, much --

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE ROBERTS
completeLines.speech: What --

completeLines.speaker: CHATMAN
completeLines.speech: -- the way.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE ROBERTS
completeLines.speech: -- good would the -- what good would the presumption do if it's just a presumption? Presumably, if it's a presumption, the prisoner is --

completeLines.speaker: CHATMAN
completeLines.speech: Uh-huh.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE ROBERTS
completeLines.speech: -- going to say, "Well, here's why you shouldn't follow the presumption in my case," just as, if it looks like he's waited a long time, he's going to say, "Well, here's why that delay was reasonable." I don't know that the presumption you're proposing serves much of a purpose.

completeLines.speaker: CHATMAN
completeLines.speech: The value of a 60-day presumption is that it saves the Federal Court from having to look at the State-law time -- of the timeliness in that particular case and --

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE ROBERTS
completeLines.speech: No, it doesn't --

completeLines.speaker: CHATMAN
completeLines.speech: -- it ought --

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE ROBERTS
completeLines.speech: -- not if the prisoner says, "Here's why you shouldn't follow the presumption."

completeLines.speaker: CHATMAN
completeLines.speech: Well, that's true. But if it ­ - but if he files within 60 days, there's no need to look further or consider his argument regarding timeliness. And the other value in the 60-day --

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SCALIA
completeLines.speech: Why phrase it as a presumption? Why not phrase it, "We determine California law to be, unless we hear otherwise, having examined what it does in other situations, that 60 days is timely"?

completeLines.speaker: CHATMAN
completeLines.speech: I think that would be perfectly fair.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SCALIA
completeLines.speech: It's the same thing. But I wouldn't call it --

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: All right --

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SCALIA

completeLines.speech: Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court: In light of Justice Breyer's questions, I feel compelled to begin with a brief explanation of why this case is a necessary consequence of Saffold. completeLines.speech: I missed it. You said the problem is, California doesn't "support" or "import"? I just didn't --

completeLines.speaker: STRIS

completeLines.speech: So, the difficulty of looking to that, which may be a good difficulty -- I mean, that is a serious problem, but I thought what we wrote in the case -- see, there are two problems here. completeLines.speech: Okay. completeLines.speech: That is correct.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SCALIA
completeLines.speech: There isn't. You --

completeLines.speaker: STRIS
completeLines.speech: There is not.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SCALIA
completeLines.speech: You mean if you go in and you say, "I'm" -- you know, it's more than 90 days, and you bring in no evidence whatever of any excuse for being over 90 days, you're telling me that California Supreme Court would accept it?

completeLines.speaker: STRIS
completeLines.speech: No, that's not true. The --

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SCALIA
completeLines.speech: Well, then --

completeLines.speaker: STRIS
completeLines.speech: -- the --

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SCALIA
completeLines.speech: -- then it is a presumption --

completeLines.speaker: STRIS
completeLines.speech: That's correct.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SCALIA
completeLines.speech: -- that if it's over 90 days, unless you have a reason, it's untimely.

completeLines.speaker: STRIS
completeLines.speech: The burden shifts the prisoner to produce some evidence. I didn't understand that to be --

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: So, here we have 180 days -- 180 days, twice 90 -- with no excuse at all presented.

completeLines.speaker: STRIS
completeLines.speech: In the noncapital context. And it's very -- it's very different, because the California State Courts are articulating particularly ­ - particular policy reasons for noncapital prisoners to delay. One that they're articulated is a desire to avoid the piecemeal presentation of claims. And this is particular to California's original writ system. You can have a functional appeal, but, because it's also an original writ, you -- if you have an additional claim that's legitimate, you need to add it in that claim.

completeLines.speaker: CONNOR
completeLines.speech: But once it's --

completeLines.speaker: STRIS
completeLines.speech: And --

completeLines.speaker: CONNOR
completeLines.speech: -- in the Federal habeas context, the AEDPA law suggests there's a great premium paid -- at stake for promptly resolving these things. What do we do about that? This is in the Federal court system now.

completeLines.speaker: STRIS
completeLines.speech: If it were the case -- and there's no evidence on the record to suggest this -- that a substantial number of cases were going to start coming through California with massive delays, and this Court was going to be forced to provide statutory tolling, that would be a problem. But there's no evidence to suggest that. And that ties back to --

completeLines.speaker: CONNOR
completeLines.speech: Well, what would we do in that situation?

completeLines.speaker: STRIS
completeLines.speech: If that --

completeLines.speaker: CONNOR
completeLines.speech: If it's --

completeLines.speaker: STRIS
completeLines.speech: -- started happening?

completeLines.speaker: CONNOR
completeLines.speech: -- open to the Federal Courts.

completeLines.speaker: STRIS
completeLines.speech: If that started happening, I think you, in this Court, would do nothing. I think that Congress would see what was going on, and they'd amend the statute, because that's clearly not what they intended. But that's not this case.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE GINSBURG
completeLines.speech: Amend just for California, when the system is working fine, all the other States that do have the timelines?

completeLines.speaker: STRIS
completeLines.speech: I don't think they would do that, Justice Ginsburg. But there's a proposal that I'm aware of, already, to change the specific language of 2244(d)(2), and it was made by a congressman in California. It doesn't suggest changing it for California; it suggests changing the language. But that hasn't happened.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE GINSBURG
completeLines.speech: To do what? What would it say?

completeLines.speaker: STRIS
completeLines.speech: I believe it replaces the word "pending" with some replacement. And so, it essentially changes the tolling provision to account for this problem. But that hasn't happened yet. Right now, we have a congressional statute that, on its face, does not require the Federal Courts --

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: What about this? You might lose under this, but it -- see, so you say -- look, in every other State, the time for appealing from an appeals court to the State Supreme Court, asking them, is 20 days, normally, or sometimes 30. So, if the Ninth Circuit gets a case in which it was longer than 30 days, then, irrespective of whether they say "on the merits," whether they cite a case, whether they don't say anything and just have a postcard, what the Ninth Circuit should assume that they've done is consider it untimely, in the absence of the kind of excuse that the California Courts might accept as an excuse. So, then they'll look into that. And if California, in the future, wants something different -- which I'd be surprised -- they will say that their system means that a 3-year delay, or whatever it is, is actually timely. But, in the absence of some reason to think that, why not use the words, which would give you a chance to go back, and you could say, "This is not a case of total lack of excuse. There is excuse of the kind that California would accept."

completeLines.speaker: STRIS
completeLines.speech: Well, I think the problem with that sort of rule, Justice Breyer, is that it risks error, because California's standard is so indeterminate, and at very little -- it gets very little benefit. Because there's -- there is no real harm -- there's no real harm to the Federal interest here just because we have a conclusive presumption. The very nature of a conclusive presumption is that sometimes there will be cases that don't fit the presumption. But, on this record, and on anything I've seen from my review of California procedure, there's nothing to suggest that a -- the Federal interest in avoiding substantial delays is compromised by the specific rule that the Ninth Circuit has adopted. And the Ninth Circuit has adopted a --

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE ROBERTS
completeLines.speech: Well, how can you -- how can you say that? We do have a Federal rule and a limitation, and (d)(2) is an exception for time that it's pending before the State Courts. And if the State Courts aren't going to bother to tell us whether something's timely or not, or pending, giving them a blank check does undermine the Federal interest behind the 1-year limitation period.

completeLines.speaker: STRIS
completeLines.speech: I would say two things about that, Mr. Chief Justice. The first thing is, I would strongly resist your characterization that the State Court is saying nothing. I think that, in most cases, they are saying something, and that, in the cases that involve postcard denials, many of them, the court is saying that they're timely, and, in others, those are the hard questions. So, I would restrict your characterization to the fact that California is not saying something in some cases. Now, because the Federal statute necessarily imports a State standard, that's the very problem with the statute. I can conceive of many instances where --

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE ROBERTS
completeLines.speech: Why do you think the Federal statute necessarily imports a State standard? It says that the State postconviction proceeding must be pending. And California presents an unusual situation, but we interpret that pending is a question of Federal law. It's not a State standard.

completeLines.speaker: STRIS
completeLines.speech: That's true, Mr. Chief Justice. But if you took that to its logical conclusion, then, when State Courts made errors -- they didn't see that a case was properly filed, they just missed it -- the Federal Court would go in and review. Or in a case where they did claim the reverse, the Federal Court could say, "No, there was clear error." But this Court has rejected that in Saffold. It's rejected it in Pace. And -- because that is informed by the very view that the tolling provision was included to encourage one round of State exhaustion free of Federal interference.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: But we decided -- I'd like you to suggest something to -- from putting yourself in the -- in an imaginary position. Carey versus Saffold did have a dissent. And four Justices joined it. And let's imagine that, when I read the dissent, I see the -- and then I look at this case -- I see imaginary words on the top of the dissent, which are, "We told you so."

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: And -- now, therefore, think not of if you were arguing Carey v. Saffold afresh, but think of the words that are actually written there. And now think of what happened here. And now propose something, please, that will, in fact, deal with the problem that this case seems to present.

completeLines.speaker: STRIS
completeLines.speech: Well, I would be lying, Justice Breyer, if I didn't say that I haven't thought about that. And the problem is that the rule announced in Saffold isn't the right rule. It's trying to deal with a problem that's been created by the California State Courts. And so, the solution that the Ninth Circuit has adopted -- that's our proposal. We essentially think that it has a minimal harm to Federal interests, because maybe certain cases will get in that Congress didn't intend, but if you don't adopt it, there's no alternative. You can't certify the question. In California, you can't certify to the Court of Appeal. You can't certify from a District Court. So, if the California State Courts aren't going to change, it's not incumbent upon this Court to read the statute differently than the proper interpretation. And I concede the arguments that were made in the dissenting opinion in Saffold are very interesting, and they don't compel, in my opinion, a different interpretation of the statute; they recognize the difficulty that the statute presents. And it presents that difficulty because it does incorporate, in some measure, a State standard, and because there's one State out there, California, that's doing something that's very difficult to deal with.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE STEVENS
completeLines.speech: May I ask this -- two questions about California? Is the problem we're discussing, with these long delays, primarily in the application the third range, the application of the California Supreme Court, as opposed to lower courts?

completeLines.speaker: STRIS
completeLines.speech: Well, I wouldn't characterize it as a problem, because, like I said before, I don't think that --

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE STEVENS
completeLines.speech: But is the condition, that there is the long delay, that primarily occurs in the ­ - in the application of State Supreme Court? Is it --

completeLines.speaker: STRIS
completeLines.speech: I have no -- I've seen no specific evidence to be able to answer that with any citation, but my understanding, Justice Stevens, is that that makes sense, because it's the last process that the prisoner is going to be able to engage in, then they'll have to go to the Federal Circuit.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE STEVENS
completeLines.speech: Then my second question is, Have we decided, or is it a matter of common practice in California, that the application to the California Supreme Court is necessary in order to complete the exhaustion?

completeLines.speaker: STRIS
completeLines.speech: It is -- it is necessary, in my opinion. I don't know if the State -- if this Court has ever --

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE STEVENS
completeLines.speech: We've held it --

completeLines.speaker: STRIS
completeLines.speech: -- decided that.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE STEVENS
completeLines.speech: -- in cases where there's direct review, but this is a different sort of animal that you have in California.

completeLines.speaker: STRIS
completeLines.speech: But once you start from the premise that these are functional appeals, which they are, I don't see how you could read AEDPA any other way. I mean, AEDPA says that if there's an available method to challenge and -- a petition, whether it be by review or original writ, to the California Supreme Court would be available. So, you could be sure that if prisoners --

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE STEVENS
completeLines.speech: I think it is --

completeLines.speaker: STRIS
completeLines.speech: -- didn't file --

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE STEVENS
completeLines.speech: -- required.

completeLines.speaker: STRIS
completeLines.speech: Yes. If they didn't file, they'd get kicked out of Federal Court.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SCALIA
completeLines.speech: There's one aspect of Saffold that you haven't addressed. We not only said what we said about they're saying "on the merits," we actually cited a case that involved exactly the situation here -- namely, Welch versus Newland, a CA9 case from 2001. And we cited that as an example of how the Ninth Circuit rule, quote, "risks the tolling of the Federal limitations period even when it is highly likely that the prisoner failed to seek timely review in the State appellate courts," close quote.

completeLines.speaker: STRIS
completeLines.speech: I would say two things about that.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SCALIA
completeLines.speech: How could the Ninth Circuit here simply have ignored that criticism of exactly what they did here?

completeLines.speaker: STRIS
completeLines.speech: Well, I don't believe they ignored it, Justice Scalia. And if you look at the Welch case that you're referring to, on en banc rehearing the en banc panel reached a very different result. They didn't reach the issue of timeliness, for the reasons I described, but they determined that that was not a functional appeal, because --

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SCALIA
completeLines.speech: But we --

completeLines.speaker: STRIS
completeLines.speech: -- the claim --

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SCALIA
completeLines.speech: -- we didn't cite the en banc decision. We cited the panel decision --

completeLines.speaker: STRIS
completeLines.speech: The en banc --

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SCALIA
completeLines.speech: -- didn't we?

completeLines.speaker: STRIS
completeLines.speech: -- decision occurred after your ­ -

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SCALIA
completeLines.speech: After.

completeLines.speaker: STRIS
completeLines.speech: -- case.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SCALIA
completeLines.speech: But the point is, we criticized the panel decision in Welch, which did exactly what this panel did here.

completeLines.speaker: STRIS
completeLines.speech: I don't agree with that characterization, Justice Scalia. I believe that case was included to illustrate that this Court thought that was probably too long, and that not looking at all to what's happening in the California system risks that. I don't think anything was at least necessary to the holding in Saffold --

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SCALIA
completeLines.speech: We cited --

completeLines.speaker: STRIS
completeLines.speech: -- because it --

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SCALIA
completeLines.speech: -- it for the proposition that it -- as an example of how the Ninth Circuit rule, quote, "risks the tolling of the Federal limitations period even when it is highly likely that the prisoner failed to seek timely review in the State appellate courts." That's what we cited.

completeLines.speaker: STRIS
completeLines.speech: That is true. And in the context of a case like Saffold, where there's a reference to lack of diligence, that risk is too great. I'm not going to get up here and suggest that there's no risk to a conclusive presumption that some cases are going to make it into Federal Court that Congress didn't intend. But it's a balancing that's inherent in the notion of federalism. There is a risk that, by not reviewing clear statements by the California State Court, that cases get in that shouldn't. A case could not have been properly filed, and the State Court didn't find it. But, in Saffold and in Pace, this Court announced the principle that once the State Court decides, that's the end of the matter. And I guess, in summation, what I suggest is that atmospherically this case presents a difficult problem. The Ninth Circuit is involved. There is a five-four decision in Saffold. We recognize those things. However, there is no easy solution. The Ninth Circuit has adopted a rule that balances the very interest in federalism that the tolling provision was intended to preserve, and there's no suggestion that some corresponding Federal interest is compromised. And, in fact, if the Federal Courts are required to review these cases, they'll be required to do it in 60 days, in 70 days, in 80 days, and, if they make a mistake, and they find a case to be untimely that the California Court didn't, will deprive first Federal habeas, one Congress didn't intend. That's fundamentally contrary to the purpose of AEDPA.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE ROBERTS
completeLines.speech: Thank you --

completeLines.speaker: STRIS
completeLines.speech: Thank you.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE ROBERTS
completeLines.speech: -- Mr. Stris. Ms. Chatman, you have 4 minutes remaining.

completeLines.speaker: CHATMAN
completeLines.speech: Thank you. Of course there's a Federal interest at stake here. It's the Federal interest in the Federal Courts not having to deal with stale habeas claims in Federal Court. One thing I'd like to address is the capital- case presumption, which is now -- excuse me -- 180 days. It's been changed from 90 days. That presumption is for -- from the filing of the reply brief to filing an initial petition in California Court. That is, your first habeas petition. That -- you only get presumed timely for 180 days. Here, we're talking about noncapital cases going just from -- taking claims, that have already been presented in one petition, to the next level. So, in those --

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: Well, 180 days from what?

completeLines.speaker: CHATMAN
completeLines.speech: From the filing of the -- the final due date of the filing of the reply brief --

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: Well, I mean, you file --

completeLines.speaker: CHATMAN
completeLines.speech: -- in the direct appeal.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: -- the reply brief in the lower court. Maybe the judge will take 4 months to decide it. What's the relation? I don't understand that. Or maybe it'll take --

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: -- 2 days --

completeLines.speaker: CHATMAN
completeLines.speech: I think --

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: -- to decide.

completeLines.speaker: CHATMAN
completeLines.speech: I think they -- I think they date it from the filing of the reply brief because --

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: Why? What would the theory be? I don't understand that.

completeLines.speaker: CHATMAN
completeLines.speech: Because they like to see these claims presented along with the appeal to be -- so that they can possibly bring them together and decide habeas claims in light of the record on appeal. So, I think that's why they date it from filing of the reply briefs.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: So, a judge -- you file it. On day -- what -- you file it on April 1st, and then the judge decides it in August. Or September. And now it's only 3 days before the 6-months -- you have to file your appeal, like, in 3 days. That wouldn't make sense. And the converse would not --

completeLines.speaker: CHATMAN
completeLines.speech: Well, you're not -- you're generally not supposed to be waiting. I mean, you were talking about claims such as --

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: You can't --

completeLines.speaker: CHATMAN
completeLines.speech: -- ineffective --

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: -- file an --

completeLines.speaker: CHATMAN
completeLines.speech: -- assistance --

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: -- appeal before -- oh, maybe you can in California. You're going to file the appeal before the lower court decides it?

completeLines.speaker: CHATMAN
completeLines.speech: Well, if we're talking about capital cases here, they are -- they are filing their appeals directly in the California Supreme Court; similarly, with their habeas petitions.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: Even -- or even before they get a lower court decision.

completeLines.speaker: CHATMAN
completeLines.speech: There would be no lower court decision.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: They don't, at all.

completeLines.speaker: CHATMAN
completeLines.speech: No.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: In other --

completeLines.speaker: CHATMAN
completeLines.speech: No, no, no.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: -- they don't, at all.

completeLines.speaker: CHATMAN
completeLines.speech: No, they go --

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: Oh.

completeLines.speaker: CHATMAN
completeLines.speech: -- straight to California Supreme Court. Which brings up one point, which is that the problem that we're looking at here in deciding timeliness will not arise in capital cases. We will not have that problem, because capital cases go straight to the California Supreme Court. There are not going to be intervals between the courts to deal with. So, that simplifies, I think, the problem a little bit. The other thing I'd like to address is the argument that a State Court is saying something with these summary orders. I strongly disagree with that. They are absolutely saying nothing. This Court said in Ylst that the essence of an unexplained order is that it says nothing. It does not say, "This is a timely petition."

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE ROBERTS
completeLines.speech: Well, the ones that would cite a case that threw out the petition because it was untimely -- and we were told there were over a thousand of those every year -- that would be saying something, wouldn't it?

completeLines.speaker: CHATMAN
completeLines.speech: That is -- in the California Supreme Court, you will find that sometimes, that they will indicate untimeliness by a case citation; hardly ever in the lower appellate court. And I would also disagree with the characterization of delay being a problem going from the lower appellate court to the California Supreme Court. We see it at both levels. And I would also disagree that this shouldn't be a problem because these Petitioners have no incentive to delay. That may be the case, that they don't have an incentive to delay, but they do, in fact, sleep on their rights, as --

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: How often --

completeLines.speaker: CHATMAN
completeLines.speech: -- Mr. Chavis did.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: Do you, as the Attorney General, what period of time after the District Courts made a decision, and now -- they've now filed their claim in the Court of Appeals -- how long is it before you say it's untimely?

completeLines.speaker: CHATMAN
completeLines.speech: We would -- we would say anything over 60 days. Yes, Your Honor. I see my time is up. Thank you.
